content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good CoC, the context is a little bit different than the other CoC and this makes it more interesting ! Solution is overall simple and everyone should give it a try

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like this clash.
It's a relatively simple problem that takes a moment to grasp from the instructions, but if you read it slowly and comprehend each sentence, it's not too complex.

Thank you for the slight wording change, this helps convey the problem 10fold (for me anyways).

Interesting cool Coc, solved in python. In Coc, the length of the context might make some players take more time to understand. Some comments : 
- Is it to possible to add  before "The rules to write a date in Latin are as follows." the following phrase : "In Latin a date always refers to a special day"  ? 
It will make the all date /special day thing a little bit easier to understand

- The formating of the special days made me thought that the "i" was a "L" as LUL.This tricked me. Maybe change it to an other word : "Mul"/"Tul"/"Rul"  

Overall  cool CoC, it might be a little too long (~7min / 10min) but I think everyone can solve it under 15 min. This needs to be in the pool of CoC in order to have more than 1min of reflexion

I like this, but struggled to grasp what was needed of me quick enough for me to approve, but I feel like it's an easy fix.

The main hurtle for me was  "If it's a special day" doesn't specify that those are the names of the special dates, but are referred to as such later in the goal. This makes it a little hard to read, but if you add few more words to the mini headings, I think it can clear this up.

My recommended revision to @ Goal:
Given a day number in July, write the corresponding date in Latin.

The rules to name a date in Latin are as follows.

<<If it's a special day, you only need to print the name of said day:>>
- July 1st --> {{Kal Iul}};
- July 7th --> {{Non Iul}};
- July 15th --> {{Eid Iul}} ;
- August 1st --> {{Kal Aug}}.

<<If it's the day before a special day, add {{prid}} before the day's name:>>
--> {{prid}} [[special_day]]
where [[special day]] is the name of the special day.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's pretty clear what you need to do. Only tricky part is finding the next special day, which can be done with a loop or even with 4 if statements. Maybe consider emphasizing that it's "IUL" and not "LUL" since the font makes them look the same

This took me about 8 minutes to solve, under 'Fastest' conditions. I see there's a rejection thread about this where you consider simplifying it by removing the Roman numerals. In my view that's not enough of a simplification to make this solvable under 5 minutes, since the conversion is quite simple when you give us a conversion table anyway.

Really the complexity is just in understanding the concept and then figuring out the next special day and how many days away you are ("d") then applying the different conditions for d = 0, d = 1 and d > 1. It's an interesting idea, but it might be a bit hard for most clashers unless you can simplify the statement a bit more to make it easier to start coding quicker instead of reading.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: it is not solvable within 5 minutes

Goal
* Please change "as follow" to  "as follows".

* Please change "1st" to "1" (twice) for consistency with how the other dates are stated in the statement.

* Please add "and" before "August 1" and "Kal Aug".

* Please format "Kal Iul", "Non Iul", "Eid Iul", "Kal Aug" and "prid" as {{constants}} and remove the quotation marks around the word/phrases.

* Please format "a d" as a {{constant}}.

* The players are not expected to have knowledge of how Roman numerals are written. Please provide *either* a full list of Roman numerals from 3 to 17, *or* an explanation of how they are written.

Input
* Line 2: Please add "space-separated" before "day numbers".

Output
* Please add "one day per line".

Constraints
* Please delete the hint.

Thanks.

Hi! Thanks for the feedback.

Can you please elaborate on what makes it too long to solve? This might help me not only for this contribution but also for future contributions I make.

In particular, was the statement easy to understand or did you need to waste a lot of time reading it? Could you easily think of an algorithm to solve the problem? Did you encounter some difficulties while trying to implement this algorithm?

I tried to make the statement as clear and concise as possible; and in fact if you follow the rules from the Goal section in the order I wrote them, it's already an algorithm:

- Identify which of July 1st, July 7th, July 15th, August 1st is the closest special day in the future
- Get the corresponding name (Kal Iul, Non Iul, Eid Iul or Kal Aug)
- Get the difference k (number of days) between the current day and that special day
- Add nothing, "prid" or "a d <k + 1>" in front of the name of the special day depending on k is 0, 1 or 2 or more.
- k+1 has to be written in Roman numerals, but I gave the full list of Roman numerals in comment in the stub, so you can just copy-paste it as a list and retrieve the kth element.

I guess I could limit to dates between July 1st and July 7th?

This way either the result is Kal Iul, or the next special day is Non Iul. So there would no longer be a need to "search" for the next special day.
Agreed here. Even though it's there for you to copy paste and use, I made this mistake. I ran the code like 4 times and stared at iul and lul thinking it says "found lul and expected lul"

An alternative solution, that, in my opinion is easier to follow, but may not keep your vision for this clash, is something along the lines of the example below. However, this may be too revealing for the logic that the clash requires.

mock-up-goal:
You will be given a date # for the month of July, and must convert it to a Latin named date.
There are three separate portions to a named date in Latin. 

Firstly, you specify its proximity to a special day.
-If it is a special day, you need not do anything extra.
-If it's the day before, you must start with {{prid}}.
-All other named dates begin with {{a d}}.

Secondly, whenever it's not the special date, nor the day before the special date, you must specify the proximity to the next special date in a Roman Numeral (list of roman numerals are provided in a comment). 

Finally, the name of the current or upcoming special day.
(list the special day)

Thank you for your comment. I added a sentence at the end to clarify that Iul is written with an uppercase i, not a lowercase L.

I cannot change it to Mul or Tul or Rul, because this is Latin and July, not Klingon and Muly.
Thanks for your reply and taking the remarks into account !
Thanks! I changed the wording slightly

I think that would be going too far, because then clashers may as well just solve it with an array and use the day numbers as indices:
["Kal Iul", "a d VI Non Iul", "a d V Non Iul", "a d IV Non Iul", "a d III Non Iul", "prid Non Iul", "Non Iul"]

If you want to go in that direction then I'd just cut out the 1 August date, so limit days from July 1 to July 15. Which could still be solved with an array of course, but you'd have to weigh up whether it's worth it a bit more now it's a 15 element array instead of 7.
I changed the Goal section to make it less verbose
Actually I'm not attached to the Roman numerals. Maybe I should remove that part and just write k+1 in decimal.
